citations.narrative:
The licensee has failed to make and keep records of acquisition and disposition pertaining to at least one dingo. A
Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (CVI) was provided by state officials showing that the facility purchased and
transported one Dingo from a Michigan zoo on December 6, 2023. This animal was not present at the facility during the
inspection. There was no record of this animal’s acquisition or disposition in the facility’s records. The licensee advised at
a previous inspection that the animal was transported to a person in Illinois for breeding, however the information of that
animal’s location (disposition) continues to not be provided. A request was made to inspect the records of the facilities
zebu located on their property that are used for sales or exhibition, and this request was denied.
The lack of records prevents the traceability of exotic animals acquired by the facility and sold to the public.
Every dealer and exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following
information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased, or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor.

citations.desc: Information as to business; furnishing of same by dealers, exhibitors, operators of auction sales, intermediate handlers, and carriers.
citations.narrative:
The licensee refused to furnish business records requested by APHIS Officials during the inspection. The facility
organizes an online auction business, acting as a broker by running an auction sale of exotic hoof stock animals including
Scottish highlanders, yak, and zebu. During the inspection, the inspector made a third request to inspect the records of
the past zebu and Scottish highlanders that were discussed the previous inspection on March 25, 2024. This request to
inspect records included those pertaining to:
- Nine zebu that were bought at an auction in MO on April 6, 2023
- Two miniature Highland cattle on February 2, 2024, for which APHIS Officials
received a copy of a certificate of veterinary inspection (CVI) from the Minnesota
Board of Animal Health
- Two Highland Cattle received on March 5, 2024, from a facility in MN.
Additionally, APHIS Officials requested to inspect information concerning the sale of at least one Yak sold through the
auction from April 24-25, 2024. State Officials provided APHIS with certificates of veterinary inspection concerning the
Yak (CVI 4-8-2024) and Highland Cattle (CVI 2-2-24 and 3-5-24), demonstrating that documentation was created. During
the inspection, the facility representative confirmed that they do maintain records of these sales. When Officials requested
to review these records, the licensee refused, stating she was not comfortable allowing inspectors access. The licensee
was reminded about requirements to furnish information that APHIS Officials request in connection with the enforcement
of the provisions of the Act and was informed that continued refusal would result in the documentation of a noncompliance
with this section. The licensee continued to refuse access to these records.
Refusal to furnish information relating to the business such as these auction records prevents the traceability of exotic
animals acquired by the facility and sold to the public.
Each dealer, exhibitor, operator of an auction sale, intermediate handler, and carrier shall furnish to any APHIS official
any information concerning the business of the dealer, exhibitor, operator of an auction sale, intermediate handler or
carrier which the APHIS official may request in connection with the enforcement of the provisions of the Act, the
regulations and the standards in this subchapter.
To be corrected by: May 19, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Critical Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee has failed to make and keep records of acquisition and disposition pertaining to at least one dingo. A 
Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (CVI) was provided by state officials showing that the facility purchased and 
transported one Dingo from a Michigan zoo on December 6, 2023. This animal was not present at the facility during the 
inspection. There was no record of this animal’s acquisition or disposition in the facility’s records. The licensee advised at 
a previous inspection that the animal was transported to a person in Illinois for breeding, however the information of that 
animal’s location (disposition) continues to not be provided. A request was made to inspect the records of the facilities 
zebu located on their property that are used for sales or exhibition, and this request was denied. 
 
The lack of records prevents the traceability of exotic animals acquired by the facility and sold to the public. 
 
Every dealer and exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following 
information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased, or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or 
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise 
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. 
2.125  Critical
   
Information as to business; furnishing of same by dealers, exhibitors, operators of auction sales, intermediate 
handlers, and carriers. 
The licensee refused to furnish business records requested by APHIS Officials during the inspection. The facility 
organizes an online auction business, acting as a broker by running an auction sale of exotic hoof stock animals including 
Scottish highlanders, yak, and zebu. During the inspection, the inspector made a third request to inspect the records of 
the past zebu and Scottish highlanders that were discussed the previous inspection on March 25, 2024. This request to 
inspect records included those pertaining to:  
-  Nine zebu that were bought at an auction in MO on April 6, 2023  
-   Two miniature Highland cattle on February 2, 2024, for which APHIS Officials  
 received a copy of a certificate of veterinary inspection (CVI) from the Minnesota  
 Board of Animal Health  
- Two Highland Cattle received on March 5, 2024, from a facility in MN.

Additionally, APHIS Officials requested to inspect information concerning the sale of at least one Yak sold through the 
auction from April 24-25, 2024. State Officials provided APHIS with certificates of veterinary inspection concerning the 
Yak (CVI 4-8-2024) and Highland Cattle (CVI 2-2-24 and 3-5-24), demonstrating that documentation was created. During 
the inspection, the facility representative confirmed that they do maintain records of these sales. When Officials requested 
to review these records, the licensee refused, stating she was not comfortable allowing inspectors access. The licensee 
was reminded about requirements to furnish information that APHIS Officials request in connection with the enforcement 
of the provisions of the Act and was informed that continued refusal would result in the documentation of a noncompliance 
with this section. The licensee continued to refuse access to these records.  
 
Refusal to furnish information relating to the business such as these auction records prevents the traceability of exotic 
animals acquired by the facility and sold to the public. 
 
Each dealer, exhibitor, operator of an auction sale, intermediate handler, and carrier shall furnish to any APHIS official 
any information concerning the business of the dealer, exhibitor, operator of an auction sale, intermediate handler or 
carrier which the APHIS official may request in connection with the enforcement of the provisions of the Act, the 
regulations and the standards in this subchapter.  
 
To be corrected by: May 19, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
